newsitem.title: UK: BP upbeat on Gulf of Mexico prospects.
newsitem.headline: BP upbeat on Gulf of Mexico prospects.

text.p: British Petroleum Co Plc on Tuesday said it expected to substantially raise its interest in Gulf of Mexico oil production in the next eight years.
The oil giant aims to boost its share in the region's oil production ventures to 300,000 barrels per day by 2005 from a current level of 80,000, said BP chief executive John Browne.
He was speaking after BP had released its first quarter results, which showed that Gulf of Mexico production had doubled compared with a year ago.
"We'll double again fairly quickly," said Browne. "We'll continue to pick up new deep water licences and go for them," he added.
BP is less successful in the West of Shetland area in the Atlantic Ocean where the company continues to fail to meet deadlines to get the Foinaven field onstream.
BP would not specify the extra costs of the Foinaven delays, merely saying that the setbacks should be viewed against favourable production results elsewhere in the world.
BP earlier said production at Foinaven was delayed again due to bad weather, after the field was originally scheduled to come onstream nearly a year ago.

Browne meanwhile pre-empted any further criticism from environmental lobby groups, by saying that BP would "not leave a stone untouched" to ensure safe production at the largely unexplored Atlantic waters north-west of Scotland.
